Triggering Event:
Fucking hell! I'm burning dinner again! How many goddamn times does this make this week? My hands are shaking as I scrape the charred remains into the trash, the smoke alarm screeching like a fucking banshee in my ears.

The kitchen's a mess - pans everywhere, ingredients strewn about like I've been robbed. And me standing here, red-faced and livid, with another ruined dinner for my husband to fucking deal with.

He doesn't understand. He can't. He goes off to his cushy office job every day, no pressure, no deadlines. No fucking sous chefs ready to mutiny if you so much as sneeze wrong.

And then there's me, stuck here, chained to this goddamn stove, expected to create fucking magic three times a day. And for what? For him to complain about the fucking salt content or ask where the damn pepper is?

I swear, I'm going to lose it on him next time he dares to say "It's not too salty, is it?" with that smug little smile of his.

Right now, though, I'm just pissed at myself. Another fuck-up added to my growing list. I can't keep doing this. Can't keep failing like this. It's driving me mad.

I slam the trashcan lid shut, hard enough to make something inside crack. Good. Let it break. Maybe that'll make me feel better.

But probably not. Not until I've calmed down and cleaned up this fucking kitchen. And then, maybe, just maybe, I'll go apologize to my husband for another shitty dinner.

Fuck my life.
Generated Assessment:
As I stood in the kitchen, staring blankly at the burnt offerings before me, I couldn't help but think of all the other couples out there who seemed to have it together. The ones who cooked up perfect meals with ease, who never had to worry about pleasing anyone else's palate. They must be having a laugh, sitting around sipping wine and enjoying a home-cooked dinner, while I was over here struggling to get even the simplest things right.

My mind wandered to my friend Sarah, whose husband always raved about her cooking. She'd whip up these incredible feasts, and he'd devour them with gusto. I bet she didn't have to deal with the same level of stress I did, juggling work and family and trying to keep everything running smoothly. And yet, when I tried to cook for my own husband, it was like I was a disaster waiting to happen.

I sighed, feeling a lump form in my throat. Why couldn't I be more like Sarah? Or, better yet, why couldn't I be the one who got to enjoy those effortless dinners, watching my partner swoon over my culinary skills? But no, instead I was stuck in this rut, constantly second-guessing myself and wondering if I was good enough.

As I began to clean up the mess, I caught a glimpse of myself in the mirror. Red-faced and frazzled, with a hint of tears welling up in my eyes. I looked like a hot mess, and I knew exactly why. It wasn't because of the burnt dinner; it was because I felt like I was failing, like I was somehow less capable than everyone else. And that thought was suffocating me.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the quiet hum of her home office, Jane's fingers danced nervously on the keyboard, each keystroke echoing like a guilty confession in the stillness. She was behind schedule, again, and the looming deadline felt like a noose tightening around her neck.

Her phone buzzed, flashing her ex-husband's name. She hesitated before picking it up, her thumb hovering over the 'ignore' button. But she couldn't ignore the familiar pang of guilt that gnawed at her whenever he called. She slid her finger across the screen, answering with a tight, "Hello?"

"Jane," his voice was warm, too warm after all these years. "I've been thinking about our last conversation." He paused, and Jane could picture him running a hand through his thinning hair, just as he used to when he was nervous. "About the house."

She felt her shoulders tense. The house they'd once shared, now sold off, the proceeds split between them. She thought she'd made it clear she didn't want anything more to do with it.

"I've been thinking," he continued, oblivious to her discomfort, "maybe we could use some of that money to help Sarah with her tuition."

Jane felt a surge of irritation mixed with guilt. Sarah, their daughter, had always been his favorite, and Jane couldn't shake off the feeling that she'd let him down by not being able to give her more.

"I've already sent her what I can," Jane said, her voice sharper than intended. "I'm swamped at work right now, Tom. I can't just—"

"Can't or won't?" he interrupted, his tone hardening. "You always did have a way of making everything about you."

The words stung like a slap across the face. Jane felt her chest tighten, her anxiety spiking. She took a deep breath, trying to keep her voice steady.

"That's not fair," she managed to say before he hung up abruptly, leaving her staring at her phone, feeling guilty and angry all at once.

She turned back to her computer screen, the lines of code blurring as tears pricked her eyes. The house, Sarah, Tom - it was all a reminder of what she'd lost, of how she'd failed them all. And now, she couldn't even focus on work without feeling like she was letting someone down.

She rubbed at her temples, trying to push away the guilt that threatened to consume her. She knew she needed to get back to work, but all she could think about was how much easier it would be if she could just... make it stop.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, my day is going great so far. Just got out of bed, spilled coffee all over my shirt, and now I'm stuck in this traffic jam. Why does this always happen to me? Can't I just catch a break for once?

I swear, every time something good comes along, it gets ruined somehow. Like, I finally landed that promotion at work, and now my boss is breathing down my neck about meeting those impossible deadlines. And don't even get me started on my love life – I met this amazing guy, and now he's ghosting me because I'm "too high maintenance".

It's like the universe is conspiring against me. Every time I try to move forward, something sets me back. My car broke down, my internet went out, and now I'm late for my shift. What's the point of even trying?

I know I need to calm down and focus on the positives, but it's hard when everything feels like it's stacked against me. I mean, who needs a smooth ride to work when you're stuck in traffic anyway? And yeah, maybe my boss is tough, but at least I'm getting paid, right?

I guess what really gets under my skin is that everyone else seems to be having it easy. My friends are all doing great, landing new jobs, traveling, and just living their best lives. Meanwhile, I'm over here struggling to make ends meet. It's just not fair.

I'll just take a few deep breaths and remind myself that it's not all bad. I mean, I do have my health, my family, and my... okay, fine, my cat. That's something, right? But seriously, why does everything have to go wrong for me?<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
A code-red alarm pierced the air as Jane rushed into the ER, her sneakers squeaking on the linoleum. Another night, another crisis in this godforsaken hospital. She'd been at it for 16 hours straight, and all she wanted was a break.

The charge nurse thrust a chart at her, "Code blues in trauma two and four. You take four." Jane grabbed the chart, scanning the details with a scowl. Mr. Thompson, 72, heart attack. Great, another one they couldn't save.

She stormed into room four, where Dr. Harris was already working on compressions. "Took your sweet time," he snapped. Jane bristled but said nothing, checking the monitors instead. Mr. Thompson's rhythms were erratic, his pulse weak and thready.

"Let me know when you're ready to call it," she said flatly, drawing disapproving looks from the residents. She didn't care. This wasn't about compassion anymore; it was about survival. Hers.

As they worked, Dr. Harris ordered another round of epinephrine. Jane watched the clock, her contempt growing with each passing minute. They weren't going to save him. Not tonight. Not with this team.

Finally, at 0235 hours, Dr. Harris called it. "Time of death..." His voice trailed off as he looked at Jane, expecting her to finish. She just stood there, arms crossed, lips pressed into a thin line.

"Let's get him cleaned up," she said finally, turning away from the body, from the team, from another goddamn failure. Another waste of her time, her energy, her life.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, great, another night, another bunch of incompetent idiots running around like headless chickens. I swear, Dr. Harris thinks he's some kind of genius just because he's got a fancy degree from Harvard. Newsflash, doc: it doesn't matter how smart you are if you can't even keep track of someone's vitals.

And don't even get me started on the charge nurse. She's always so cheerful, like everything is just peachy keen. But I know what she's really thinking - that I'm the worst nurse ever and she's stuck with me because nobody else wants to touch this mess.

I mean, seriously, who takes 16 hours straight? Me, apparently. And now I've got to deal with Mr. Thompson's family, who are probably just going to freak out and make things worse. I can already hear them crying and wailing, asking why we couldn't save their precious grandpa.

Dr. Harris is probably thinking I'm just a big baby, that I need to toughen up and stop whining. But honestly, can't he see that I'm just trying to survive here? We're all just trying to make it through the night without losing our minds.

And another thing, why does everyone always assume I'm the one who messed up? It's never me, it's always someone else. The doctor, the nurse, the intern... whoever it is, they're always pointing fingers and blaming me. Like I'm some kind of superhero who can fix everything with a few magic words.

But no, I'm just a cog in the machine, a replaceable part. And if I don't shape up and start pulling my weight, I'll be the next one to go. Joy. Just what I needed, more stress and anxiety to deal with.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the heart of the bustling kitchen, Emma slammed her hands onto the prep table, sending carrots flying. Her eyes blazed as she glared at the clock, its hands mocking her with their steady ticking. It was the anniversary of his death - a year since her husband's sudden heart attack had left her alone in this chaotic world of sizzling pans and clattering knives.

Today, every dish seemed to remind her of him. The sautéed mushrooms, his favorite; the creamy risotto, their shared comfort food on cold winter nights. She could almost hear his laugh echoing through the now-silent apartment they once filled with love and warmth.

Her rage simmered like the pot of boiling water beside her. It bubbled over when she found a crumpled note from the sous-chef, suggesting they "move on" to lighter dishes for the season. As if they could just replace his favorites with something more trendy, more forgettable!

Emma's hands trembled as she gripped the counter, her knuckles turning white. She wanted to scream, to throw plates, to reduce this kitchen - their shared dream - into a chaotic mess of shattered glass and scattered ingredients. But she didn't. Instead, she stood there, trembling with suppressed anger, tears pricking at the corners of her eyes.

The oven timer dinged, snapping her back to reality. She took a deep breath, steeling herself against the grief threatening to consume her. Tonight's special would be his steak, cooked rare just like he liked it. And she'd serve it with a side of rage, hidden beneath a forced smile and a quiet, "Bon appétit."
Generated Assessment:
As I watched Emma's outburst in the kitchen, I couldn't help but feel a sense of frustration. The way she lashed out at the clock, as if it were personally responsible for her husband's passing, struck me as unfair. Why did she need to bring up such painful memories every day? Couldn't she just focus on cooking dinner?

I remembered the conversation I had with her earlier today, when she mentioned how much she missed her husband. I tried to reassure her that time heals all wounds, but she just shook her head and said she wasn't ready yet. Now, it seemed like she was taking it out on everyone around her - the sous-chef, the other cooks, even the kitchen itself.

It's not like we're trying to replace her husband's favorite dishes or make her forget about him. We're just trying to do our jobs and provide a good meal for our customers. But Emma's behavior made it seem like we were somehow to blame for her pain.

I decided to speak with her manager about the situation, hoping that a gentle reminder about customer service might help Emma get her emotions under control. After all, someone has to keep things running smoothly in here, especially on days like today.

As I continued prepping for the evening rush, I couldn't shake off the feeling that Emma's behavior was going to affect not just her own performance, but also the rest of us who worked hard to maintain a welcoming atmosphere for our guests.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
"I do hope you're enjoying your Saturday, because I most certainly am not," she muttered, glaring at the email that had dared to appear in her inbox during what was supposed to be her day off. As a scientist, she was used to long hours and relentless pursuit of knowledge, but this...this was too much.

"Dr. Amelia Hartley, you are invited to attend the wedding of your ex-fiancé, Dr. Henry Thompson, and his new...what shall we call her? His new 'colleague', I suppose," she sneered, the word leaving a bitter taste in her mouth. She hadn't heard from him since their acrimonious split six months ago, and now this?

"Oh, how delightfully ironic," she said, her voice dripping with sarcasm as she read on. "The ceremony will take place at the very lab where we first met, where we fell in love, where we planned our future together. How quaint." She felt a lump form in her throat, but she refused to cry. No, she would not give him the satisfaction.

She poured herself a glass of wine, the sound of liquid hitting crystal echoing through her empty apartment. "To Henry," she toasted, raising her glass before taking a large sip. "May your wedding day be as cold and sterile as your lab."

She threw the invitation onto the table, watching it flutter to the floor like a discarded piece of trash. She was sad, yes, but more than that, she was angry. Angry at Henry for moving on so quickly, angry at herself for still caring, angry at the world for being so cruelly indifferent.

"I suppose I should be grateful," she said, her voice barely above a whisper. "At least he had the decency to invite me. Perhaps he wants me to see how happy he is without me." She took another sip of wine, letting the alcohol burn away the tears that threatened to fall.

"No," she declared, standing up and walking over to the trash can. She dropped the invitation in, watching as it landed on top of the crumpled remains of her lunch. "I will not go. I will not watch him celebrate his happiness while I'm left here, alone."

She took one last look at the invitation before closing the lid, sealing away the pain along with the hateful piece of paper. She wouldn't go to his wedding, but she would also refuse to let it ruin her Saturday. Instead, she turned on some music, poured herself another glass of wine, and got back to work. After all, there was nothing like losing oneself in the mysteries of the universe to forget about the pain of the present.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, great, just what I needed to make my already mediocre Saturday even more tolerable - a reminder that everyone else has their life together except me. I mean, who needs personal fulfillment when you've got a decent paycheck and a comfortable apartment, right? 

I scrolled through social media, watching as my friends and acquaintances posted updates about their exciting weekend plans. A group of them were heading out to a concert, laughing and joking around like they owned the place. Meanwhile, I was stuck at home, nursing a hangover and wondering why I even bother getting out of bed in the morning.

And then, I saw it - a post from my ex's new girlfriend, flaunting her perfect smile and flawless skin. Like, hello, I'm over here trying to adult and pay my bills on time, and she gets to spend her days lounging by the pool, sipping margaritas. It's just not fair.

I couldn't help but think about how I must be doing something wrong. Why did I end up with someone as toxic as Henry, while she lands a catch like him? Is it because I'm just not good enough? Because I don't have the right looks or the right connections? Ugh, it's just so frustrating.

But hey, at least I've got my science degree to fall back on. That's gotta count for something, right? I mean, I'm basically a genius, and yet I'm stuck in this dead-end job, while she's off living her best life. It's just not fair.

I tossed my phone aside, feeling a surge of anger and resentment towards the universe. Why does everything always have to be so unfair? Can't anyone just give me a break for once? I swear, sometimes I feel like I'm the only one who's really struggling here.

But then, I looked around my cluttered apartment, at the stacks of unpaid bills and the worn-out couch. And I realized that maybe, just maybe, I'm not as bad off as I thought. Maybe I'm actually pretty lucky to have made it this far. So, I took a deep breath, grabbed my guitar, and started strumming. Time to lose myself in the music and forget about all my problems.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
As she rang up Mrs. Thompson's purchases, Emma felt her cheeks flush. She'd known the elderly woman since childhood, yet today, she couldn't quite meet her gaze. Yesterday's argument with her husband echoed in her mind, his harsh words stinging like a physical blow.

"Thank you, dear," Mrs. Thompson said, patting Emma's hand as she accepted her change. Emma managed a weak smile, but her eyes flicked to the door, longing for escape from the weight of her embarrassment and the sympathetic gaze of someone who knew too much about her life outside this shop.
Generated Assessment:
As I stood behind the counter, ringing up Mrs. Thompson's purchases, I couldn't help but notice the faint blush that had crept onto her cheeks. It was almost...amusing, really. The way her eyes darted towards the door, searching for an excuse to flee, was almost pathetic. 

But what struck me most was the forced smile plastered on her face. It was clear she was trying to hide something, but I wasn't buying it. Her attempt at small talk was stilted, lacking the warmth and familiarity that usually accompanied our interactions. 

It was almost as if she was trying to pretend everything was fine, when in reality, I could sense the tension beneath the surface. The way her hands trembled ever so slightly as she took her change was a dead giveaway. 

And then there was the fact that she seemed to be avoiding eye contact altogether. It was almost...intentional. A deliberate attempt to sidestep the issue at hand. But I wasn't having it. I would get to the bottom of things, no matter how uncomfortable it made me feel.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event: In the chaos of the ER, she missed it. A faint beep, her husband's phone vibrating on the counter. She was elbow-deep in a patient's IV line, her mind racing with vitals and meds. Later, alone in their kitchen, she noticed the notification: "You have 1 new voicemail." Her stomach knotted. Why hadn't he answered? She dialed, listened to the message - static, muffled voices, then silence. She called back, again, no answer. Where was he? It was almost midnight. Anxiety prickled her skin. She texted, "Everything okay?" No reply. She paced, checked the locks, double-checked her phone. Still nothing. What if...? She shook her head, trying to dislodge the worry that threatened to consume her. Where was he?
Generated Assessment:
As I stood there, frozen in uncertainty, my mind began to wander down a narrow path of possibilities. Either he had abandoned me, leaving me to face this chaotic night alone, or he was simply indisposed, perhaps stuck in traffic or caught up in some unforeseen circumstance. The thought of him deliberately ignoring me was unbearable, yet equally, the notion that he might be genuinely busy or distracted seemed implausible. 

How could one person so callously disregard another's distress? His silence was akin to a deliberate rejection, a cold, calculated move that left me reeling. And yet, I couldn't shake off the nagging doubt that perhaps I was overreacting, that his absence was merely a minor oversight. But what if it wasn't? What if this was a test of our relationship, a trial by fire that would reveal its true mettle? 

In that moment, I felt like I was trapped between two opposing certainties – either he loved me unconditionally, or he didn't. There was no middle ground, no room for nuance or ambiguity. My thoughts careened wildly between these two poles, refusing to settle on anything less than absolute certainty. As the minutes ticked by, my anxiety grew, fueled by the conviction that I was staring into the abyss, with no safety net to catch me if I fell.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the quietude of her quaint cottage, where the ticking of the grandfather clock echoed like a metronome counting out the interminable seconds, Edith sat alone at her dinner table, the remnants of an uneaten meal growing cold before her. The once vibrant hue of the roses in their vase now drooped, mirroring her own spirits that had wilted over time.

The silence was deafening, save for the occasional hoot of an owl outside, a lonely sound echoing through the night. It was on such nights that memories crept in like unwelcome guests, uninvited yet impossible to evict. She remembered her late husband, Harold, his laughter filling their home, his warm hand enfolding hers during meals. Now, only empty chairs and echoes remained.

Tonight's intrusion was a memory of young Emily, the infant she had cared for as if she were her own granddaughter. Emily, with her rosy cheeks and infectious giggles, now a teenager with a life far beyond Edith's reach. The child she had loved and lost, not by death, but by time's relentless march forward.

Edith looked at the framed photograph of Emily, taken on her first birthday. She remembered the party they'd hosted, Harold's pride as he watched his granddaughter blow out her candle, Edith's heart swelling with love. Now, it was just another photo gathering dust, another memory fading into the cobwebs of time.

She felt a lump form in her throat, tears pricking at the corners of her eyes. The unhappiness was a weight she carried, a silent companion that refused to leave her side. She missed the warmth of Harold's hand, the joy of Emily's laughter, the simple pleasures of their shared life. Her heart ached with a profound loneliness, a void that seemed impossible to fill.

As she stood to clear the untouched dishes, the old floorboard creaked underfoot, a sound that once signaled Harold's approach. Now, it was just another reminder of his absence, another trigger for her unending unhappiness.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, every time I'm alone in this stupid cottage, I feel like I'm drowning in my own misery. Every night, it's the same thing - darkness, emptiness, and these goddamn memories that won't leave me alone. I swear, it's like the whole world has moved on without me.

I mean, what's the point of even having a house when it's just going to be me, sitting here, feeling like crap? The silence is suffocating, and I can practically hear Harold's ghost whispering in my ear, reminding me of all the good times we had. But let's be real, those days are long gone. He's really gone, and I'm stuck here, alone, with nothing but my thoughts to keep me company.

And don't even get me started on Emily. That little brat's grown up and moved away, leaving me with nothing but a bunch of dusty photos and faded memories. I used to think I was doing something right, taking care of her like she was my own daughter. But no, I guess I wasn't enough. She's off living her best life, and I'm stuck here, rotting away.

I look around this room, and it's all just a reminder of what I've lost. The flowers are dead, the furniture's outdated, and the pictures are just a bunch of useless relics. I might as well be living in a tomb. And the worst part is, I know I'll never find happiness again. I'll be stuck in this rut forever, reliving the same miserable moments over and over.

The floorboards creak, and I swear, it's Harold's voice, calling out to me. "Hey, Edith, how's it going?" No, it's not him. It's just the damn house settling. But it doesn't matter. My mind's made up. I'm a lost cause, and I'll never escape this prison of my own making.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the bustling ER, Nurse Elizabeth's crisp whites were immaculate, but her patience was fraying like an old bandage. A young, tattooed man, barely conscious and reeking of whiskey, was wheeled in by EMTs. His slurred words were a symphony of profanity, each one grating on Elizabeth's already raw nerves.

"What'd you do this time, Jamie?" she snapped, not bothering to hide her irritation. "Fall off your barstool again?"

Jamie sneered, his bloodshot eyes meeting hers with a challenge. "None of your business, Nurse Ratched."

Elizabeth's hands tightened around the clipboard. She was not in the mood for this. Not today. Not ever since John's passing. Every drunkard reminded her of him, and Jamie was no exception.

"I'll give you 'none of my business'," she hissed, leaning into his face. "I've got a corpse at home who didn't choose to drink himself stupid. You want to join him? Keep mouthing off."

The ER fell silent, except for the beeping monitors and Jamie's sudden, sheepish silence. Elizabeth stormed away, leaving orders in her wake like a trail of fire. She'd seen enough blood today; she didn't need any more on her hands. Not from some punk who thought life was one big party.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, I'm telling you, every drunk comes in here like Jamie - completely out of control, spewing filth everywhere. It's like they're trying to make my job harder on purpose. I swear, I've had it up to here with these idiots. They think they can just waltz in here, stinking up the place, and expect me to cater to their every whim. Newsflash: I don't have time for that crap.

And don't even get me started on the way they talk. It's like they think they're above everyone else, with their condescending attitude and their "I know better" nonsense. Well, let me tell you something, buddy - you don't know squat. You're just a drunk, stumbling around like a fool, and you're going to end up hurting yourself or someone else if you keep this up.

I mean, seriously, what's wrong with these people? Can't they see that they're making a mess of things? That they're putting themselves and others at risk? No, instead they just keep on drinking, and drinking, and drinking, until they end up in a hospital bed. And then they wonder why we're so mad at them.

It's like they think they're entitled to special treatment or something. Like they can just come in here, break all the rules, and expect us to roll over and let them do whatever they want. Well, let me tell you, that's not how it works. We're not here to coddle you, we're here to help you when you need it most. But you have to meet us halfway.

So, yeah, I'm done with Jamie. Done with the whole scene. I'm just going to go ahead and assume that every single drunk who walks through those doors is going to be a handful. Because, let's face it, that's just what they are. A handful of trouble, waiting to happen.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In his seventh decade, Harold, an esteemed artist known for his intricate landscapes, lived alone in a quaint cottage nestled near the woods he often painted. His once vibrant, now silver hair was always disheveled, a testament to his absorption in his work.

One crisp autumn morning, Harold received a letter from the local art council. He sliced open the envelope with his palette knife, an unhurried ritual honed over years. As he unfolded the paper, his eyes scanned the neat lines of text, his expression growing more sour with each sentence.

The council had decided to award this year's prestigious grant not to him, but to a young upstart who had barely stepped into the world of art. They praised her "raw talent" and "fresh perspective," words that grated on Harold's ears like nails on chalkboard.

He scoffed, his lip curling in contempt as he tossed the letter onto his cluttered worktable. "Raw talent?" he muttered, his voice dripping with derision. "She wouldn't know technique if it bit her on the canvas." He picked up a brush and began to clean it, his movements precise, almost angry.

Harold turned to look at his latest painting, a scene of the woods ablaze with autumn colors. He had poured years of experience into capturing the essence of those trees, their leaves like flame under his skilled touch. And yet, they chose some fledgling over him?

His hands trembled slightly as he dipped the brush into the solvent. "Well," he said to the empty room, his voice steady despite the emotion churning within him, "I suppose it's time I showed them what an 'old hack' can do."
Generated Assessment:
Another year, another rejection. It's not like I'm getting any younger or anything. The art council thinks they're so much better than me just because I've been around for decades. Newsflash: age has nothing to do with talent. I mean, have they seen my portfolio? My paintings are masterpieces. I've spent years perfecting my craft.

But no, they have to go and give it to some...some...young whippersnapper. Raw talent, indeed. Like anyone who's ever picked up a brush knows how to paint. I swear, it's all about luck these days. They must have made a mistake. But I doubt it.

And what really gets my goat is that they praised her "fresh perspective". What does that even mean? That she doesn't know any better? Please. I've got a fresh perspective too - one that comes from years of hard work and dedication. But do they care about that? No, they just want someone new and exciting to fawn over.

This is ridiculous. I demand a recount. Or better yet, I'll just show them what real art looks like. Time to dust off the old brushes and prove them wrong. Again. Ugh, why do I always get stuck with the short end of the stick?<|eot_id|>
